translated: 2. Record of Exploring the Profundities of the Flower Ornament Sutra, Scroll 19, ending with the sixth ground of knowledge
Wei Kingdom Xisi Temple Monk Fazang's Commentary
Below, it clarifies the ten good and wise advisors, with ten people each corresponding to one position.
In the first, the practice of joy, there are also five parts.
In the first, raising the Dharma and encouraging practice, the country is called saving and crossing because it always uses the Dharma and wealth to give to all.
Moreover, practice can save things, so it is called saving.
Causing them to attain the supramundane, it is also called crossing.

The bhiká¹£u Good Manifestation is a bhiká¹£u whose appearance surpasses others, indicating that internally he accomplishes practice and externally manifests superior rewards, thus called Good Manifestation.
Encouraging to go and asking about the Dharma, etc., can be known.
The second, from at that time, below, is following the teachings and entering. First, contemplating the previous Dharma, then gradually reaching the later position.
In the previous, the first sentence generally contemplates the previously manifested gate of universal adornment;
The eleven sentences below are specific, the first is what is realized;
The second is the basis;
The third is what is crossed;
Fourth, what is practiced is also the naturelessness of conditioned activities;
Fifth, the mind that is free from arising and ceasing in a moment;
Sixth, the appearance of illusions like light;
Seventh, contemplating the true nature of principles;
The next two contemplate the meaning of words;
The last two contemplate cause and effect.
Third, below in the city, in the section on seeing, respecting, and requesting, first, seeking and discerning.
In the city and so forth, seeking to illustrate the practice of non-attachment, cultivating according to conditions.
Second, below seeing that bhiká¹£u, clarifying the superior characteristics seen.
It is said that he was walking in the forest, illustrating the characteristics of transcending the world, and also showing the place of practice.
Next, the superiority of the direct embodiment, illustrating that practice accords with the Buddha's fruition, therefore the characteristics are the same as the Buddha's.
The chapter on the grounds says, Only by practicing as taught can one attain the holy Dharma, this is what is meant.
Next, below celestial dragons, it clarifies the superior retinue and the various offerings made.
Third, below at that time, setting up respect and requesting can be known.
The fourth, from he replied below, shows his own Dharma realm.
In this, there are three parts:
First, showing the Dharma obtained through conditions; second, from good man below, revealing the function of the Dharma; third, from I only below, concluding the name of the Dharma gate.
In the first, there are also three:
First, the young one who has just left home; the days are close means that he has just entered the stage of practice, so he is called young.
He has just left the home of the ten abodes, so it is said the days are close.
Second, from I myself below, it clarifies the Buddhas he has made offerings to.
The previous stage had thirty-six, but here it gradually increases, so it is eighteen eons.
Also, it says since I was born as if in one lifetime he has gone through that many eons making offerings to those Buddhas.
What is the meaning of this?
The explanation says:
Either the life span is extremely long;
Or one lifetime encompasses many eons, like an instant encompassing an eon, and so on;
Or entering the Buddha's teachings for rebirth, saying, Since I was born in this bodhi mind, I have passed through so many kalpas and made offerings to so many Buddhas.
Also, the Nirvana Sutra speaks of making offerings to Buddhas for eight eons and subsuming the stage of causes, and so on.
Third, in the presence of those Buddhas clarifies the cultivation of practices and attainment of dharmas.
One sentence is general;
Second, adornment and below are the three kinds in the specific, which are:
First, concentration and vows, second, praising practices, and third, perfection and below are the complete virtues;
Third, adornment and purity and below explain the three causes, which can be known in sequence.
Second, the eleven phrases on karmic functions all first clarify the karmic functions and then bring out the causes.

The first three are the power of the previous concentration and vow adornments, the next one is the power of the previous universal practices, and the remaining seven are the power of the previous bodhisattva practices and vows.

Among them, the first two making offerings to Buddhas and hearing the Dharma are the previous knowledge of bodhi and protection of the Dharma wheel, the next two are the profound cultivation of concentration, and the last three are the vast objects of knowledge.

As for the third, the name of the samÄdhi, it is called lamp of light because it illuminates far and wide, and it is called following because the ten inexpressibles and so forth are always used without exhaustion.
The Indian original is named Bodhisattva Liberation of the Lamp of Unceasing Wisdom.
In the fifth section on looking up to and promoting the superior progress, this is the looking up to and promoting of the same kind.
First, it shows the superiority of the birth and clan;
Second, the superiority of the life span. Although one has reached an inexpressible eon in the past, one has not yet attained immortality, so it is promoted now;
Third, the superiority of the retribution body, namely, the inexhaustible inner wisdom and the indestructible outer form;
Fourth, Universal Observation and below clarify the superiority of the karmic function;
Fifth, How can I and below conclude that it is not one's own part.
The first stage of joy is completed.

In the second stage of benefiting, first, it raises the Dharma and encourages cultivation. Internally, the first country is named Suna, which means pure and also good. This is the name of a great river.
It means that the country has this river, and is named after the matter.
All non-Buddhist and worldly people say:
By bathing in this river, all sins are eliminated and blessings increase, hence the name.
It symbolizes the practice of upholding precepts and abandoning unwholesome actions.
The boy named Åšakra, the Lord of the Devas, the boy symbolizes the purity of the practice of precepts;
He is in control of the precepts, hence the name Lord of the Devas.
According to the original text from India, he should be named Master of All Faculties, as the Sanskrit name Indra means Åšakra and lord.
Indriya means faculties.
SvÄmin means master or lord.
Since the Sanskrit words for Åšakra and faculties are similar, each is named after one of them.
Second, encouraging him to go and ask for instruction.

In the second part, At that time, Sudhana, following the teachings and entering, first it shows the arising of superior thoughts, second it shows paying respect and taking leave, and third it shows arriving together with the assembly.
In the third part, seeing, paying respect, and making requests, first it shows seeking and announcing.
Good city is also a name for Sona. Originally in India, the city was called good, but it is said to be outside the city, symbolizing that precepts are the external defense of practice.
Beside the river symbolizes the arising of the water of concentration.
The river is the same as the river there.
Second, seeing what they were doing, playing in the sand, illustrates the arising of the number of precepts in the three collections.
Third, setting up respect and fourth, making a request, can be understood.
Fourth, below answering, it shows one's own Dharma realm.
There are three parts in this:
First, citing the essence of the Dharma gate; second, below Good man, I because of..., clarifying the function of karma; third, below I only..., concluding the name.

In the first part, Manjushri's teaching clarifies that people can protect precepts and therefore know the characteristics. The ten wholesome deeds are auspicious, and the ten evil deeds are inauspicious.
The characteristics of precepts are not one, therefore it is said to be the method of counting.
The Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom says: The precepts of bodhisattvas are as numerous as dust motes.
The principle of good and evil causes and effects is definite, therefore it is called the Dharma of seals.
Moreover, some people explain: the first is inauspicious, which eliminates the precepts of the Vinaya;
the next is to calculate good, which always cultivates the precepts of wholesome conduct;
the last is to seal the capacities, which is the precept of saving and nurturing sentient beings.
Because of this, one attains all skillful techniques and so forth. Skillfully knowing worldly dharmas transforms into the function of transcending the world.
This is the knowledge of skillfully transforming all dharmas that I attained in India.
In the second, demonstrating the functions, there are two parts:
First, revealing the functions of the two dharmas of characteristics and seals, because with characteristics one knows good and evil and seals away calamities, therefore they are discussed together.
Second, below Furthermore, demonstrating the skillful abilities of the calculation method.
Laksha means ten thousand.
Third, concluding one's own part can be known.
In the fifth, below the great bodhisattvas, promoting the superior progress, first generally mentioning what is being promoted, and then below I shall, correctly promoting what is not one's own part.
The second practice of benefiting others is complete.

In the third, the practice of non-anger and resentment, first it raises the Dharma and encourages cultivation. As for dwelling in the city of the ocean, if explained according to characteristics, this city is located near the southern ocean.
If following the text below, it refers to the inexhaustible giving of wealth and Dharma, thus it is called dwelling in the ocean.
The upÄsikÄ named SvÄmin, in terms of practice, means patience that is free from anger and delusion, thus called self-mastery.
If in terms of virtue and function, it means acting according to one's will, thus called self-mastery, which is what is revealed below.
The name in the Indian text is Satyavati.
The explanation says:
It is because wealth and Dharma are universally sufficient.

In the second, at that time Sudhana and below, following the instructions to seek, first it clarifies obtaining the perfuming and cultivation, second it sets up respect and takes leave, and third it laments and praises the virtues with ten pairs that can be known.
In the third, seeing, respecting, and making requests, first it clarifies the expedient means of entering the Dharma;
Second, below entered is the manifestation of seeing the true body. The removal of ornaments and wearing plain clothes symbolizes the appearance of forbearance.
Third, below in the palace is the manifestation of seeing the dependent environment. Opening four gates symbolizes the four means of gathering disciples to benefit beings.

Fourth, below ten thousand women is the manifestation of seeing the excellent retinue. Among them, the sound of speech and the fragrance of the body benefit beings with great wisdom. Making offerings and requesting the Dharma.
Fourth, below she replied is the correct manifestation of the Dharma realm. There are three parts:
First, raising the essence of the Dharma gate; second, below with one vessel is the manifestation of function; third, below I only is the conclusion of the Dharma belonging to oneself.
In the beginning, because the manifestation of function is inexhaustible, it is called the inexhaustible treasury.
The tools for benefiting beings that are produced have excellent virtues, so it is called the adornment of merit and virtue.
Second, in the function, there are three parts:
First, the manifestation of the function of the Dharma gate; second, below you see my is the manifestation of the same benefit; third, below just wait is the verification of the present.
The first part is in three sections:
The first is the benefit of giving food and so forth to sentient beings, the second is the benefit of giving to the two vehicles and so forth, and the third is the benefit of giving to bodhisattvas.
In the first section, the ancient commentaries say:
The one vessel of food is the one-flavored true suchness that is the basis for the superior flow.
According to their desires means teaching the Dharma in accordance with the capacities of beings.
Without increase or decrease means using it without exhaustion.
There is another interpretation:

It is just one vessel of rice, which is fused with the inexhaustible dependent origination of the Dharma realm. Therefore, there is nothing that does not accord with the capacities of beings, and there is nothing that does not benefit those whose capacities are met, and there is nothing that does not accord with the Dharma realm of one's original state. Therefore, it says according to their desires without increase or decrease.
In the second section on showing the same benefits, there are two parts:

First, it mentions the same karmic retribution and so forth of one's own retinue, with twenty-eight phrases. The first ten phrases are called the skillful means practices of one's own benefit, the next four phrases on the same realm are the same Dharma cultivation, and the next fourteen phrases on the same possession of bodhisattvas are the same fulfillment of one's own and others' practices.
Second, These bodhisattvas and below reveals the appearance of one's own inclusion and accomplishment.
Third, Good man, just wait and below uses the present event to verify accomplishment.
Third, I only and below concludes the name, which can be known.
In the fifth, praising and promoting, first specifically promoting what is being promoted, second concluding it is not one's own realm.
The third, the practice of no anger, is complete.
In the fourth, the practice of no exhaustion, first raising the Dharma and encouraging practice. The city is called Great Prosperity because diligence blazes.
Moreover, it is widely used to raise and accomplish great giving with wealth and Dharma, so it is named.
The elder is explained as before.
The essence of diligent practice is the most supreme among flavors, so it is called nectar.
The virtue of practice surpasses, expressed like the peak.

Second, At that time, Sudhana and below, according to the teaching, enters. First, setting up respect and saying goodbye, second, At that time and below, recollecting the previous Dharma, third, Gradually and below, reaching the later position.

The third part, pervading, is the section on seeing, paying respect, and making requests. First, seeking; second, starting the superior desire below seeking with joy; third, seeing the superiorä¾æ­£ and superior retinue; fourth, paying respect; fifth, making requests about the practice.
The fourth part, the elder replied, is the section on showing his own Dharma realm. First, generating the mind;
second, Good man, you see me and below, the Dharma encompasses the retinue, causing them to accomplish ten kinds of benefits, which can be understood.
Third, the name of his own Dharma door is proclaimed, namely the inexhaustible treasury of wealth and Dharma contained in space, giving according to one's wishes, and thus it is named.
Fourth, according to their needs and below clarifies the function of the Dharma door. First, generally speaking, the treasury of meritorious treasures benefits beings according to their wishes;
second, just wait and below uses events to verify the accomplishment.
First, seeing the assembly gathering;
next, observing the rain of objects from the sky, this is the same as the samÄdhi of breaking through the container of empty space, which is precisely what is attained in the ten practices;
finally, bestowing the Dharma to bring joy.
Fifth, concluding one's own Dharma door.
In the fifth, praising the superior progress, first generally praising, second, below that is to say, there are ten specific phrases, third, below I should, concluding it is not one's own realm.
Fourth, the chapter on inexhaustible practices is concluded.

In the fifth, the practice of leaving delusion and confusion, first raising the Dharma and encouraging practice, inside the city named Lion's Multi-storied Building, the ten virtues are stacked up, resembling a multi-storied building.
The courageous and valiant ones dwell in that position, therefore called lion.
This building is in that city, the city is named after the building, thus it is named.
The elder Dharma treasure CÅ«dÄ means CÅ«dÄ means topknot, then using Dharma to form a person.
Treasure is the topknot.
The Indian original says there is a Dharma elder named RatnacÅ«á¸a.
Revealing the precious and supreme characteristics of the function of his samÄdhi.

In the second, going to the place of practice according to the teachings, first, making respectful salutations and taking leave; second, contemplating and cultivating the previous Dharma door to promote growth; third, gradually reaching the next stage. The text can be seen.

In the third, thoroughly seeking, the section on seeing, making offerings, and requesting the Dharma, within this, encountering and seeing on the way, clarifies the power of the Way to accord with conditions and respond to things as they are.
In the fourth, at that time, the elder, the section on bestowing one's own Dharma realm, within this, there are four parts:
First, holding hands and so forth is the method of bestowal, which is the stage of added effort;
Second, thoroughly observing and so forth is the correct seeing of the Dharma realm, which is the stage of penetrating insight;
Third, asking about the causes and conditions of the Dharma, which is the stage of subsequent understanding;
Fourth, I only... and so forth, concluding what one knows, which is the stage of establishing the name.
In the beginning, holding hands and leading back, it shows embracing and returning to what is realized.
Just observe my home is using the Dharma to bestow correctly.
In the second, Subsequently, Sudhana... the section on realizing and seeing the Dharma realm, first, observing in general.
Second, The house was vast is the specific observation.
It is said that this house has ten stories, which is the highest level.
The characteristics of this are difficult to determine, so I will briefly give three explanations.
First, relying on the ancient masters, they say:
The ten stories are the ten grounds.
Because the eightfold noble path is used to enter and roam, it becomes the eight gates.
Or the four means of conversion and the four immeasurables are also the eight gates.
The first giving of food refers to the practice of giving in the first ground.
The second giving of jeweled garments refers to the garments of shame and conscience in the second ground.
The third giving of jeweled ornaments refers to the practice of forbearance in the third ground, which is used to adorn the body.
The fourth giving of inner retinue refers to the auxiliary practices of the four dharmas in the fourth ground.
The fifth gathering and compiling the true Dharma, etc., refers to attaining the five treatises on logic, etc., in the fifth ground.
The sixth attaining the perfection of wisdom, with bodhisattvas filling it, etc., refers to attaining the great wisdom of prajÃ±Ä in the sixth ground, which manifests in three ways:
First, generally revealing profound wisdom;

Second, the specific manifestation of ten aspects below the two, the first is illumination is quiescence, the second is quiescence is illumination, the third is external conditions do not turn, the fourth is internal illumination is free from defilement, the fifth is the essence is firm, the sixth is the function is vast, the seventh is containing excellent virtues, the eighth is seeing the Dharma realm, the ninth is many skillful means, the tenth is conforming to the capacities of beings, the eleventh is manifesting by analogy, because this is an increasing number.
Third, compiling this below concludes the extensive and manifests the concise.

Seventh, the Bodhisattvas of the Resounding Patience, etc., attain the supreme practice in the middle of the seven grounds, know the various teachings have no different meanings, and accomplish the patience of echoes.
Eighth, the Bodhisattvas of Constant Abiding, etc., here there are two virtues:
The eighth ground realizes the non-increasing and non-decreasing Dharma realm;
The spiritual powers, lands, etc. are because of mastery over the three worlds.
Approaching all, etc. clarifies the ninth ground receiving and upholding the Buddha Dharma.
Ninth, the Bodhisattvas of the Position of Filling the Place, etc. clarifies the tenth ground receiving the position of authority, etc., which is also the stage of equal enlightenment.
The tenth is the stage of all tathÄgatas, which is the state of wondrous enlightenment.
From the initial arousal of the mind of enlightenment and so forth, it clarifies the inclusion of causes and the attainment of fruition.

The second further explains these ten levels, which are all the stages of these ten practices. Beginning with the practice of giving food, it is called the practice of joy, up to the tenth, which is the practice of truth where tathÄgatas are replete. It is because in a single stage all stages are included.
This has two layers:
The first is using the ten practices to include the ten abodes and the ten practices of faith, and the latter to include the stages of turning toward and the ten grounds.
The second is that since the ten practices include all the stages, within the fifth practice itself, it includes these ten practices.
Previously, the bhiká¹£u SÄgaradhvaja was in the stage of the ten abodes. The Buddha on the crown spoke the Dharma, and still used the gate of the ten abodes to include all stages.
Now, this elder is in the stage of the ten practices. The house he resides in still uses the gate of the ten practices to include all stages.
This is the same as the meaning subsumed in both places, but previously it was explained based on the sixth abode, while here it is distinguished based on the fifth practice.
Moreover, previously it was based on the Buddha at the peak, while here it is based on the one dwelling in the house, both of which are to illustrate the difference in superiority and inferiority.
The third interpretation:

Overall, it is not based on stages, but this bodhisattva, based on practice and responding to capacities, manifests dwelling in superior traces and bases, and explains ten to manifest inexhaustibility:
The first four are giving things, the first is easy and the latter is difficult;ğŸ”½The next two are gathering the Dharma, the first is shallow and the latter is deep;
The next two are receiving the Dharma, the first is narrow and the latter is broad;
The latter two manifest superior virtues, first the cause and then the effect.
In total, these ten stages all gradually become subtle from coarse, which can be known.
Moreover, this elder comprehensively includes the dharmas of cause, effect, practice, stages, etc., and is generally the basis, therefore it is taken as the house.
Third, in the subsequent attainment, the original cause of the Dharma is revealed. Within this, there is first a question and then an answer.
In the answer, the wholesome roots are dedicated to three places. First, eliminating poverty and suffering refers to the first four of the ten grave offenses, which are their retribution.
Second, seeing Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, etc., and third, always hearing the true Dharma, these two are above the fifth grave offense, which is their retribution.
Therefore, the one who attains this retribution dedicates to the three places and fulfills the ten grave offenses.
Fourth, I only concludes the name of the Dharma. The three places sought by past vows are fulfilled and perfected, so it is called the Dharma door of fulfilling great vows.
The Indian text says: Attaining the Bodhisattva liberation, called the adornment of the path of unobstructed vows.
The explanation says:
The house of ten grave offenses is called adorning the path.
Past vows penetrate the subtle, called unobstructed vows.
Then, using the power of those unobstructed vows to adorn this dwelling place is called the path.
In the fifth, praising and recommending, first, distinguishing ten phrases, all saying inconceivable means that virtue is complete, there is no further progress, and it is not moved by conditions.
I should... and below concludes it is not one's own part.
Relying on the Sanskrit text says:
How can I know their virtues and speak of their practices?
Explanation:
It means one cannot understand the virtues they have already accomplished, and cannot speak of the practices they are currently engaged in.
The texts above and below are all the same as this, one should know.
The fifth practice is completed.

In the sixth, the knowledge of the practice of good manifestation, first, citing the Dharma and encouraging practice, inside the country called Real Sharp Roots, a country is the boundary and position.
PrajÃ±Ä, free from inversions, is called real, and illuminating and giving rise to later [stages], is called sharp roots. This is relying on a place to manifest the sixth practice.
A city is the defense against the outside and the protection of the inside, which is the function of wondrous wisdom.
Universal means concisely taking the broad, and gate means universally entering and traversing.
Universal is the gate, and the universal gate is the city, both of which are explained as holding their own nature.
This is explained in terms of the Dharma.
Another explanation:
The city encompasses the retinue, and because it is the destination of many, it is called the universal gate.
This is explained in terms of events.
The elder Pumeyan Miaoxiang uses wisdom to illuminate the roots and medicines of sentient beings, and universally perfumes them, thus giving him his name.
In the second part, following the teachings and entering, there are three parts: parting, thinking, and arriving.
In the thinking, there are ten sentences:

The first sentence generally thinks of the previous Dharma, the next two sentences clarify what is obtained through thinking, the next sentence is seeking without weariness, the next three sentences accomplish the roots and powers of the bodhisattva's liberation, the next two sentences are the practice and vows following the mind, and the last sentence obtains the essence and function of wisdom.
In the third part, seeing, respecting, and requesting, there are four parts: seeking and heading towards, thinking, seeing the superiorä¾æ­£, making offerings, and requesting.
The fourth, bestowing one's own Dharma realm, has three parts:

First, praising the arousal of the mind as a skillful means for bestowing the Dharma; second, I know all... below this, bestowing the Dharma gate's functions; third, I only... below this, concluding the Dharma's name and essence.
Within the functions, there are two:
First, healing illnesses and universally transforming, benefiting sentient beings below;
Second, I am also skilled in... below this, using fragrances to give rise to practices, making offerings to the buddhas above.
The first has four parts:

First, removing their physical suffering; second, bestowing them with physical bliss; third, Then, for them... below this, healing their mental illnesses; fourth, Praising... below this, correctly bestowing the great practices.
Within these four, the first two together bring peace and bliss to sentient beings, which is also a skillful means for embracing and transforming;
The latter two are benefiting sentient beings, which is also correctly bestowing the Dharma practices.
Within the fourth, there are fourteen phrases:

The first three are the methods for bestowing the mind of enlightenment, because they are the basis of practice. First, praising the Buddha's merits causes one to give rise to the mind seeking omniscience. Second, the mind of great compassion saves sentient beings. Third, the pure wisdom of the perfections is the mind of disenchantment with conditioned phenomena, and it is also the mind of extensively cultivating superior practices.

Speaking of the great vows and the following eleven phrases correctly bestow the methods of cultivating the ten perfections. First, based on the great vows, one practices giving and embraces sentient beings, up to the last two phrases which manifest the perfection of wisdom.

In the second, the practice arising from incense, first one knows the essence of all fragrances, second one burns incense and gives rise to vows, third one universally permeates according to the vows and forms great offerings. The text can be seen, because in the Sanskrit text it is a seller of incense.
In the third, concluding the name and essence, causing sentient beings to rejoice is as explained above, benefiting and delighting sentient beings.
Universal gate is as explained above, burning incense universally permeates and adorns the Dharma realm.
Seeing all Buddhas is because they are the Buddhas to whom offerings are made.
The original text from India says:
May all sentient beings be content and universally see the Buddha's fragrant body Dharma gate of offerings.

In the fifth section on praising and advancing further, the first sentence mentions the person, the next sentence generally praises the great benefits, and the third sentence below Those who see specifically praises the benefits of seeing.
I should concludes that it is not within one's own capacity.
The sixth stage is completed.

In the seventh stage of the knowledge of the practice of non-attachment, the first is to cite the Dharma and encourage practice. The city is named Full Banner because the conditions for the realm of skillful means are complete and surpass others.
The king is named Fulfilled because the wisdom of skillful means is perfect and one has mastery over adversity and favor, so the king is again used to represent this title.
In the second part of seeking according to the teachings, there is first taking leave, then thinking, and finally arriving.

In the recollection, the first sentence is the general recollection, because this non-attachment is the skillful position, and it generally includes the dharmas of the previous positions, saying recollect in order and so forth, this then recollects the teaching dharma;
second, and then and below recollects the human power;
third, thus and below clarifies that by means of recollection one attains superior progress.
The great mind has sixteen sentences:
first, the nine sentences are the mind of one's own practice, second, seeing the buddhas and below is the mind of attaining superior progress.
The third, seeing and respecting, requesting and applying, has seven parts:
first, the question and answer pointing out;
second, seeing from afar the king and below seeing the superiorä¾æ­£;
third, seeing the contrary characteristics;
fourth, giving rise to doubt and fear;
fifth, the empty heavens deciding for him, in which there are two parts:

first, raising the previous teaching's truthfulness to prevent the arising of doubt, second, the bodhisattva's skillful means and below clarifying the later practice's profundity and secrecy to cause him to believe and enter.
The first is that the previous good and virtuous friend taught you to come here, and their teaching is not false, so why give rise to doubt?
Question:
Didn't Sudhana himself remember the previous teaching? Why did he give rise to doubt?
Answer:

Because it is a matter of anger and harm obstructing the path, it is necessary to have doubt in principle, only then can it reveal the difference between the two practices of going against the path and following the path in the bodhisattva path.
Otherwise, the true and the false cannot be distinguished.

The Liang lun (Treatise) explains the profundity in the precepts study as follows: The bodhisattva, by means of such skillful means and wisdom, commits the ten acts such as killing, yet without the fault of defilement, gives rise to immeasurable merit, and quickly attains supreme enlightenment.
It is necessary for a great bodhisattva to be able to carry out this matter, and there are two kinds of this:
one is actual practice, and the other is transformation.

As for actual practice, it is knowing that the person in front will certainly commit the acts of immediate retribution, etc., and there is no other means to make them avoid this evil, only by ending their life can they be made to not commit evil.
Moreover, one knows that this person, after abandoning the body, will certainly be reborn in a good destination.
Moreover, the bodhisattva thinks:
If I engage in killing, I will certainly fall into hell and suffer for them.
Although they are currently experiencing a little light suffering and distress, in the future they will certainly receive the fruit of happiness.
The explanation says:
This is the same as what is said in the Chapter on Morality of the Bodhisattva Ground in the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra.
The second is transformation, like King Naraka and the youth Sudhana, who either see lovable things or see frightening things, each causing sentient beings to be born in a good place.
The explanation says:
The sutra cited by them is transformed.
Naraka is a Sanskrit word meaning full.

As for or see lovable things, it refers to the previous passage, first seeing the dependent and the correct giving rise to lovability, and later seeing the violation of the king's laws and so forth giving rise to fearfulness, all for the sake of benefiting beings.

Second, in the profound and secret deeds of the bodhisattvas, the first two lines are about the difficulty of conceiving the skillful wisdom, and the latter five lines are about the difficulty of conceiving the activities. That is to say, the traces contradict the practice, and those of lower positions cannot fathom it, so it is said.
Sixth, making offerings.
Seventh, formally requesting.
Fourth, below at that time, King SÄtyaka, it clarifies bestowing one's own Dharma realm, which has two parts:
First, the expedient means of bestowing the Dharma, that is, holding hands and leading them in, subsuming their practices and causing them to enter true realization.
Second, below Good man, you should observe, it directly shows the Dharma realm, causing them to realize accord. Within this, there are five parts:
